document.text: y CA88IE BALDWIN Election Day was rainy. That has gone Labor Day, Halloween and Columbus Day all gene. So we look forward to the days growing shorter and Thanksgiving and Christmas coming. Helen Inge and Louise Roach attended the World Day of Prayer at Spout Spring Baptist Church on Monday. Phyliss Richardson and Ruby Almond attended the graveside service at Ever green for Malcolm Womack on Monday morning. The Friendship Circle met with Florence Ranson on Tuesday afternoon. Eleven were present. Mrs. Margaret Marshall entered Virginia Baptist Hospital on Tuesday after noon.  Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hipps went to Roanoke Tuesday night to get their son, Gregg who had been stationed in  Texas for sometime. He will be here for several weeks. Randy Hipps Qf Blacksburg will spend the weekend here. Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Webber Mr. and Mrs. James Daubenspeck were called to Lynchburg Sunday due to the death of Mrs. Mattie Webber at Lynch burg General Hospital. Funeral was held at Diuguid Funeral Home on Tuesday in Madison Heights. Henry Ray Webber was  pall bearer. Ida Ledbetter was Mrs. Mattie Webbers sister. Sympathy is extended to these families. Katherine Dickerson sp ent Wednesday night with Pearl Wilson who is back home after a stay in the hospital for a few days. A speedy recovery is wished her. Zane Hamlin was rushed to Lynchburg General Hos pital Thursday morning early and operated on. He was quite sick for awhile, but moved to a room on Friday. May he have a speedy recovery. Lloyd and Otis Richardson and Toby Inge went to see Zane Hamlin on Thursday

document.text: WILLIAM R. LEE  William Robert Lee, 42, died Friday at 645 p.m. at his home after a long illness. document.text: We did not, in last weeks issue, give our readers an account of the occurrences at the Spout Spring recinct on election day, because we did not know, when we went to press, the true facts in the case and preferred to say nothing on the sub ject until we were fully informed thereon. We have heard the statements of the three judges and constable, F. Martin, all of which we give as well as the general facts we have gleaned that our readers may draw their own conclusions. The election at this precinct be gan in a quiet and orderly manne with Messrs. Lantech Jones, It. G Whorley and G. W. Diuguid as udges, Mr. F. L. Martin as consta bleand Messrs. F. B. Jones and John Overton as clerks. After nine votes had been regularly polled, negro named Henry Hughes weut into the booth to get Constable Mar tin to fix his ticket. Mr. Martin told him he would assist him by pointing ont the names to him. Thi Mr. Martin d id and poiu ted c u tTren tl name and Floods name both of which he scratched and then pointed out Smiths name which he scratche when the negro stopped and said You have scratched Mr. Colli us name, the very man 1 wanted vote for. The constable replied, You are a d ----- -n liar  if you dont like that ticket get anothe one and fix it to suit yourself. The negro then folded the ticket up and without makiug the slightest com plaint voted it. He weut out and iu about ten minutes Mr. E. F. Col tinswent into the election room and demanded the removal of the con stable, on the ground that he was not treating him fairly. The judges refused to make the removal. After short interval Collins, D. V McKinney and Hughes went int the room and behind them on the porch and on the ground was crowd of between twenty and thirty McKinney in a very excited way de maiided the removal of the consta ble and threatened blood-shed if he was not removed. The judges again refused to remove him, when Me Kinney and his backers grew mor violent. Mr. Diuguid, the liepuii can judge,was m favor of the rernov aud finally Mr. Whorley, because he thought otherwise that violence would be done the constable, advis ed him to leave. This the consta ble refused to do. But Mr. Whor- ieys suggestion to Martin, that lit leave, being construed iuto his con sent to his removal he was hustled out anti a Populist constable putin. At the time of this occurrence there was but one Democrat ou the grounds, besides the election officers. Mr. Martin was not a.new consta ble, but the same one who acted at the same place last Fall and one Whtr gave satisfaction tw-all parties, as is shown by the depositions of Dr. D. Mott Robertson and Mr. E. F. Collins, both of whom testified iu the Yost-Tucker contest, to his fairness and honesty. Here is what the officers of elec tion say about the occurrence. Mr, Lamech Jones appended to the certificate on the poll books the following statement Mr. K. G. Whorley also signed this statement, but later scratched his name off as he was one of the Commissioners of Election. The statement is as follows  As Judges of Election at Spout Spring, at the election held for officers, May 23d, 1895, we wish to make a statement as to the removal of Fitz Lee Martin, the regularly appointed constable.

document.text: The matron of honor was M ts . Norman Russel Adams of Farm ville. Her street length dress was emerald Green velvet, princess lino, trimmed with an obee knot in the back. She carried a bouquet of red poinsettas. The bridesmaids were Mrs. .Terry, Arnold George of Appomattox, Mrs Robert Higgins, of Richmond, and Miss Margareta Blanton Spencer, also of Richmond. document.text: The followers of the Third parly in Appomattox assembled here on Wednesday to send delegates to the Lynchburg Convention, which meets on the 3d day of August. There were eighteen Third party people present, not enough to act as delegates and alternates from the county, as Apppmattox is entitled to eleven delegates and eleven alter nates. Thos.O.Diuguidwasoneofthe speakers of the occasion. He made some wild statements in regard to the T imes , but constdering the fact that Mr. Diuguid when attempting to make a speech is like a wild bull in a china shop, we were not sur prised that his speech should have partaken of that character. Mr. Diuguid was replied to by Mr. S. L. Ferguson, the representative of the T imes present, to whom the courte sies of the floor were extended. A f ter Mr. Ps speech, Mr. Diuguids motion was promptly voted down. A more detailed statement of the meeting is given in another column.

document.text: Spring M ills Item s. Quite a pleasant sociable was held at the new and pretty residence of Mr. Jack Cardwell on the evening of the 14. After the girls had found their corresponding hand kerchief they repaired to the din ing-room, where a most, sumptuous repast awaited them. Rarely has it beeu our pleasure to see a prettier table. The evening was spent very delightfully in music and games and not tell the wee sma hours of the morn did the pleasant party think of disbanding. The gentlemen present from a distance were Messrs. Richard Webb Diuguid, John Overton, Elbert Jones, Marvin Jones, Spout Springs Eddie and Ben Caldwell, West Appomattox. Mr. Moore, from Lynchburg. Mr. and Mrs. John Davis cele brated their fifth anniversity by having a wooden wedding. Many nd nsef nl were the wooden presents tendered them. Mr. Harvey Dedaker and wife spent several weeks with their son, J. W. Davis, dinings and tea-parties were the order of the day during their stay. They left amid the egrets of all, and wishes for a speedy return. The gentlemen seem to be waiting for the reversion of the order of things as it is leap year as they have sent out but few valentines. But the girls are sure to take ad vantage of the le-p year privilege.  L eon adas .

document.text: Robert M. Moore Robert Melvin Pete Moore, 52, of 1120 Heath Ave., died Tuesday at his home. Born in Campbell County, he was a son of Josie Johnson Moore and the late Gordon F. Moore. He was a member of Chestnut Hill United Methodist Church, Moose Lodge No. 715 and Fallen River Country Club of Appomattox. He was the manager of the mechanical maintenance department at the Babcock and Wilcox NFD. Other than his mother, he is survived by his wife, Aleene Graham Moore a son, Stanley D. Moore of Concord a brother, James T. Moore of Hyattsville, Md., and a grandson. Funeral services will be con ducted at Diuguid Memorial Chapel at 2 p.m. Thursday, with burial in Spring Hill Cemetery.

document.text: Robert Julian Jenks Jen kins. 74, of 3521 Demott St., died Saturday at Virginia Baptist Hospital. He was married to Alma Inge Jenkins. His first wife was Beulah Crews Jenkins of Altavisita. Born in Appomat tox, he was the son of Addie Cawthorne Jenkins of Lynch burg and the late Robert Smith Jenkins. He was a member and on the Administrative Board of Park View United Methodist Church. He was a member of Travelers Protection Associa tion and the Quarter Century Club. He worked at Craddock- Terry Shoe Corp. for 42 years. He is survived by one son, Richard L. Jenkins of Pitts burgh, Pa. two brothers, Harry L. Jenkins of Appomat tox and Richard T. Jenkins of Luthersville, Md. one sister, Mrs. Francis Abbitt of Lynch burg, and two grandchildren. Funeral services were held at 3 p.m. Monday at Diuguid Memorial Chapel, with burial in Fort Hill Memorial Park.

document.text: Rev. John Ward, 78 years old, a well- known Baptist clergyman of Isle ol Wight county, was found dead in bed. Mr. Ward, who was chaplain of the Cal- ott-Wrenn Camp of Confederate Vet erans, delivered the prayer at Isle ol Wight Courthouse -uesday, when the Confederate monument was unveiled in the presence of 4,000 persons. He was in his usual health at bed time. The deceased is survived by a widow and two sons Dr. J. W. Ward and Robert Ward. As the result of an accident on May IO, when he was bruised internally by being thrown from a buggy, Frank E- Stallings, a justice of the peace, at Buckhorn, Nanseniond county, dit-i iged 50 years. Justice Stallings horse became frightened at a pile-driver, and he jumped to escape more serious dam- ige. Mrs. ouise Fletcher oreene, of Rap pahannock, has been appointed to rep resent the Valley of .Virginia at the reunion of Confederate veterans to be held in Louisville this month. She lias selected Miss Brucie Funkhouser, of Strasburg, as her maid of honor. Major F. R. Lassiter sued the city of Petersburg for 3,560 because the ity erected a smallpox hospital on a farm adjoining his estate. J. C. Reed, of Evansville, Ind., was held in Petersburg charged with being passer of bogus checks. A syndicate has been formed to bund an electric railway to connect Ocean View and Pine Beach. The distance is ave miles, but 300,000 capital will be raised to build hotels and cottages along he line. Stewart Terry, the 15-year-otd son of Mr. W. L. Terry, a well to-do farmer, living near Lynchburg, was kicked by horse and is probably fatally injured. Jose Antone Peria, a fireman on the steamer City of Augusta, which has taken the place of the Hamilton between Norfolk and New York, is in St. Vin cents Hospital, Norfolk, seriously wounded, and Eugene Lianas, a Portu guese mess boy on the same steamer, is in jail charged with attacking him. The boys fought. Perias wounds are in the shoulder and were inflicted with a sharp carving knife. , A dispatch from King William Court house says that Henry Lipscomb, a farm er of Manquin, that county, is probably fatally injured as the result of an attack made on him with a pitchfork by a small negro boy. The boy became angered at something said to him by Lipscomb, and attacked the farmer, driving the fork into his body 15 timds. The reunion of Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the Valley, under the auspices of the lodges of Shenandoah county, occurred at Mount Jackson There were about 1,500 persons present. Dr. C. A. R. - Moore, Mayor of Mount Jackson, made the address of welcome This was followed by a speech of ReV E. E. Northern, past grand master of Winchester, upon the origin and growth of the Order of Odd Fellows. Mr. F. P. Brumback, of Woodstock, introduced the orator of the day, Gov. A. J. Mon tague, who made a splendid speech on Odd Fellowship, which was enthusias tically received. Sands  Oliver, contractors for the first 100 miles of the Tidewater railway, have begun clearing the rights of way at Suffolk for the roadbed. Managet Dupuy is ready to advertise for bids fot another section of the road. Thomas S. Nunnally and George By rum were indicted in the Corporatioi Court at Norfolk for non-support. Nun nally was required to give bond of 120 to insure the payment to his wife of 30 every three months, and Byrum was re quired to give a bond of 150 for the payment of 3 a week to his wife. Th order in each instance is to remain in force for 12 months, with the alterna tive of staying in jail. John P. Branch, one of Richmond wealthiest bankers, has giveh 30,000 to Randolph-Macon College, at Ashland, to be used in the erection of a dormi tory. Mr. Branch is a stanch friend of the college and has heretofore made large donations. Concluding a six days trial in the Circuit Court of Surry county, the 5,000 damage suit of James H. Dillard against Mayor George H. Woods and Police Chief Kemtnerer, of Claremont, ended in a mistrial. The suit was warmly contested by five attorneys. Dillard seeks damages because of alleged illegal arrest on account of his refusal to pay town license claims. Laughton Diuguid, aged 22 years, son of William D. Diuguid, a prominent bus iness man of Lynchburg, killed himself at his home shortly before noon by blow ing the top of his head off with a Win chester rifle. The young man was suf fering from nervous breakdown, caused by overstudy during the past term at school in Philadelphia, where he was taking a course in chemistry. He had to return home some weeks ago and was to be taken to Richmond for special treatment. He did not want to leave home, and the departure was delayed. Diuguid secured the rifle, went to hts room, and, placing the muzzle against his right temple, fired. The Elks have begun the erection of their  Home, on High street, Char lottesville, opposite the Courthouse. United States Marshal Morgan Treat will remove the headquarters of the Eastern district from Newport News to Richmond. The Merchants and Farmers Bank has been organized at Smithfield, with 30,000 to 50,000 capital stock. The officers are W. P. Wilson, president B. P. Gay, vice-president W. R. My ers, cashier.

document.text: On June 18 of this year Mr. and Mrs. John Diuguid of Sykesville, Md., along with their son and grandson, three generations of Diuguids, witnessed the placing of a brass bar emblem at the base of the grave of George Duiguid. It was in the fall of 1962 that John Duiguid contacted the Lynchburg Chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of American Revolution to have his ancestors grave marked with 9 DAR marker. He contacted the Lynchburg Chapter because in his research on George Duiguid, he found that a Miss- Mabel Davidson of Appomattox had joihed the Lynchburg Chapter in 1916 as a descendant of George Duiguid and his wife, Nancy Sampson Duiguid. We ned the poll books because they only certified the number of the otes, and the certificate of remov- not because we thought it right, but simply to carry the election in. L a m ec h J o n e s . Mr. R. G. Whorley 8 statement agreed almost entirely with M Jones  he did not believe Mr. lartin had done anything wrong or ntended to do anything wrong that he did not consent to Mr. Mar- ns removal, but advised him to leave because he feared violence ou Id be done him. Mr. Geo. W. Diuguid said he be- ieved the only wrong Mr. Martin did was to swear in the booth and for that reason he was in favor of moving him. That when McKin ney, Collins and Hughes came iu he voting room with the large crowd it their back, McKinney said unless Martin was removed blood would be pilled. . Mr. Martiu being seen said, that he had been constable in the Fall lection and had then performed his luties fairly and honestly that he had no other intention in this election, that he had never received i suggestion or an instruction from my one as to his duties, except a .opy of the election law that he intended to point out the names honestly to all parties who asked his issistance aud told him they could not read that he did this for Henry Hughes and that said Hughes liad scratched Flood, Tent and Smith from the ticket, that Hughes said to him you have scratched Mr. Collins name, the very man I want to vote for. This naturally incensed him aud he cursed the negro, and told him if he did not like that ticket to get another one and fix it to suit himself. Hughes then picked the ticket up and voted it without mak ing any complaint to the judges, that complaint was made against him and he was told by one of the judges that if he did not leave he would be mobbed. His. reply was let me stay.here until they mob me, In some way he was removed. He did not leave voluntarily and never would have done so. The above are the facts of this matter and we do not believe that any law-abiding citizen will approve the high-handed and lawless meth ods adopted by the Republicans on this occasion.
